title: One million delayed flu jabs prompts emergency government purchase
text:
More than one million flu jabs will arrive late in Britain this winter, forcing the Government to order emergency stocks.

It emerged last night that Sanofi Pasteur, one of three suppliers of the vaccine for adults under 65, will fail to deliver all its vaccine doses by the October 31 deadline.

The French pharmaceutical company blamed international demand, an “unexpected delay” in its manufacturing process, as well as the World Health Organisation’s late decision over which strains to target.

The delay has forced Matt Hancock, the Health and Social Care Secretary, to order an additional 400,000 doses to prevent GP surgeries running short.

The run-up to last year’s flu season was beset with reports of GP surgeries running out of flu jabs due to uneven distribution of the vaccine.

But Professor Jonathan Van Tam, Deputy Chief Medical Officer for England, said Mr Hancock’s action meant there was “no possibility” of shortages.

“We do recognise that it’s an extraordinary year,” he said, adding that he believed Sanofi Pasteur has “robust” systems in place to get its delayed one million jabs into the UK in November.

The flu season usually begins in the early weeks of December.

A flu jab will be offered to all primary school children for the first time this year, while a new form is available for adults that is manufactured using cells instead of hen's eggs.
